DIAG_EN.description: Enable-disable pin for diagnostics, internal pulldown

connected_components.description: A digital output pin from the MCU can be used to control the DIAG_EN pin, enabling or disabling diagnostics as needed. The MCU's I/O voltage should be compatible with the DIAG_EN pin's voltage levels (0.8 V low, 1.5 V high).

If the DIAG_EN pin is not used, it can be left floating, but connecting it to GND is recommended to ensure diagnostics are disabled. An external pulldown resistor (RPROT) can be used if a specific pull-down strength is required, though the internal pulldown is generally sufficient.

implementation.connectivity: The DIAG_EN pin is an input and should be connected to a microcontroller's digital output pin or directly to GND if diagnostics are not needed. It has an internal pulldown resistor.
implementation.detailed_description: The DIAG_EN pin is used to enable or disable the diagnostic features of the TPS1HTC30-Q1. When DIAG_EN is high, the device's diagnostic functions (such as open-load detection, short-to-battery detection, and accurate current sensing) are active. When DIAG_EN is low, these diagnostic functions are disabled.
functionality: Enable diagnostics: When DIAG_EN is high, diagnostic features are active.
Disable diagnostics: When DIAG_EN is low, diagnostic features are disabled, and the SNS pin is in a high-impedance state. This also reduces standby current consumption in the off-state.

Control for off-state diagnostics: In the off-state (EN low), when DIAG_EN is low, the device enters standby mode with minimal current consumption. When DIAG_EN is high in the off-state, the device enters standby mode with diagnostics enabled, resulting in slightly higher standby current.
precautions: Ensure the voltage level applied to the DIAG_EN pin is within the recommended operating conditions (typically -1 V to 5.5 V).
If the DIAG_EN pin is not used, it is recommended to connect it to GND to disable diagnostics and minimize standby current. Leaving it floating can lead to unpredictable behavior.
When using the DIAG_EN pin to multiplex diagnostic signals with an MCU, ensure proper timing and signal management to avoid conflicts or erroneous readings.

DIAG_EN.name: DIAG_EN

EN.description: Input control for channel activation, internal pulldown

connected_components.description: A digital output pin from a microcontroller that can provide logic HIGH (e.g., 1.8V, 3.3V, or 5V) to enable the switch and logic LOW to disable it.
The device has an internal pulldown resistor on the EN pin, ensuring the switch remains disabled if the pin is left floating. Its typical resistance is between 200 kΩ and 500 kΩ.

implementation.connectivity: The EN pin should be connected to a microcontroller output or a logic signal that can drive it HIGH to enable the switch and LOW to disable it. It has an internal pulldown resistor.
implementation.detailed_description: The EN pin serves as the input control for channel activation. When driven HIGH, it enables the high-side switch, allowing current to flow from VS to VOUT. When driven LOW, it disables the switch, blocking current flow.
implementation.functionality: The pin's primary function is to enable or disable the high-side switch. It is compatible with 1.8-V, 3.3-V, and 5-V logic levels.
precautions: Ensure the voltage applied to the EN pin is within the recommended operating range (–1 V to 5.5 V) to prevent damage.
If the EN pin is left floating, the internal pulldown resistor will keep the switch disabled. If the channel needs to be enabled, a strong HIGH signal must be applied.
The input voltage hysteresis for the EN pin is 280 mV, which should be considered for reliable switching, especially in noisy environments.

EN.name: EN

FAULT.description: Open drain global fault output. Referred to~~FLT,~~ or fault pin

connected_components.connection_details: Connected to an input pin of the MCU to receive fault signals.
Connected between the FAULT pin and the microcontroller's supply voltage (e.g., VCC) to provide a defined high state when no fault is present.

implementation.connectivity: It is an output pin and should be connected to a microcontroller's input pin. An external pull-up resistor is required. If the FAULT pin is unused, it should be left floating.
implementation.detailed_description: The FAULT pin is an open-drain global fault output. It is referred to as FLT or fault pin. When a fault condition occurs, this pin is pulled down to GND.
implementation.functionality: The FAULT pin's primary function is to signal a fault condition. It is an open-drain output, meaning it requires an external pull-up resistor to indicate the fault state. If this pin is left unused, the system cannot read faults from the output.
precautions: An external pull-up resistor is required for the FAULT pin to function correctly.
If the FAULT pin is not connected to the system, fault information cannot be read.
The FAULT pin is open-drain, so it should not be directly connected to a voltage source without a current-limiting resistor if that source is not a microcontroller input.

FAULT.name: FAULT

GND.description: Ground of device. Connect to resistor- diode ground network to have reverse battery protection

connected_components.details: This network is recommended for reverse battery protection. The specific components (resistor and diode) and their values should be chosen based on the application requirements and protection level needed, as discussed in Section 8.3.5.6.

implementation.connectivity: Connect to the ground plane of the circuit. For reverse battery protection, a resistor-diode ground network is recommended.
implementation.detailed_description: Ground of the device. It is recommended to connect to a resistor-diode ground network for reverse battery protection.
implementation.functionality: The GND pin serves as the ground reference for the TPS1HTC30-Q1 device. It is also connected internally to the thermal pad, which aids in heat dissipation.
implementation.precautions: Ensure the GND pin is properly connected to the circuit ground. When using a GND network for reverse battery protection, it's crucial to follow the recommendations in the datasheet (Section 8.3.5.6) to ensure proper functionality and prevent damage to the device or connected components, especially the microcontroller I/Os.

GND.name: GND

ILIM.description: Adjustable current limit. Short to ground or leave floating if external current limit is not used

connected_components.purpose: To set the current limit threshold. The value is calculated using the formula R_LIM = K_CL / I_LIM_REG, where K_CL is the current limit ratio (100 A*kΩ) and I_LIM_REG is the desired current limit in Amps.
Connection point for the external current limit resistor (R_ILIM) and for setting the internal current limit to 16A.

implementation.connectivity: Connect an external resistor (R_ILIM) between the ILIM pin and the device's GND pin to set the desired current limit. If an external current limit is not needed, the pin can be left floating or tied to GND to utilize the internal current limit options.
implementation.detailed_description: The ILIM pin is used for adjustable current limit setting. It allows the user to define the current limit threshold for the device. By connecting an external resistor from the ILIM pin to GND, a specific current limit can be programmed. If the ILIM pin is left floating or out of range, an internal current limit of 8A is set. If the ILIM pin is shorted to GND, an internal current limit of 16A is set.
functionality: Adjustable current limit programming via an external resistor.
Internal current limit set to 8A when left floating or out of range.
Internal current limit set to 16A when shorted to GND.
precautions: When using a GND network (which creates a voltage shift between the device GND and board GND), the ILIM pin must be connected to the device GND.
The capacitance on the ILIM pin should be kept below approximately 100 pF to ensure the stability of the current regulation loop, especially when dynamically changing the current limit.
Ensure the ILIM pin is connected appropriately to achieve the desired current limit behavior. Leaving it floating results in an 8A limit, while shorting to GND results in a 16A limit.

ILIM.name: ILIM

LATCH.description: Thermal shutdown behavior, latch off or auto retry, internal pull down

connected_components.connection_details: Can be connected between the LATCH pin and ground. If the system has limited I/O and latched behavior is desired, this resistor can be used to control the latch function of multiple high-side channels.
connected_components.purpose: To control the latch function of multiple high-side channels if system I/O is limited, or to influence the auto-retry behavior.

implementation.connectivity: The LATCH pin has an internal pulldown resistor. It can be left floating or connected to ground through a resistor (RPROT) if latched behavior is desired but the system has limited I/O. If auto-retry is desired and no external control is needed, it can be left floating or connected to ground.
implementation.detailed_description: The LATCH pin controls the behavior of the device after a fault condition, specifically for thermal shutdown events. When this pin is set to a logic low, the device will attempt to auto-retry after a fault. If a latched behavior is desired but the system has limited I/O, this pin can be used to control the latch function of multiple high-side channels.
implementation.functionality: The LATCH pin determines whether the device will automatically retry after a fault or if it will latch off until the EN or LATCH pin is toggled. If left floating, the device performs an auto-retry.
implementation.precautions: If the LATCH pin is left floating, the device will perform an auto-retry after a fault. If latched behavior is required, ensure it is properly controlled, either by grounding it through a resistor or by using a microcontroller output. Be mindful of the internal pulldown resistor when driving this pin with a microcontroller.

LATCH.name: LATCH

implementation.connectivity: The NC pin should not be connected to any external circuit. It should be left floating and unconnected in the schematic and on the PCB.
implementation.detailed_description: The NC pin (pin 11) on the TPS1HTC30-Q1 is designated as 'No internal connection'. This means that there is no internal circuitry connected to this pin within the integrated circuit.
implementation.functionality: The pin has no internal functionality. It is present on the package for mechanical or manufacturing reasons, or to maintain pinout compatibility with other devices. It does not actively participate in the device's operation.
implementation.precautions: It is important not to connect anything to the NC pin. Connecting it to any voltage source, ground, or signal line could lead to unexpected behavior, damage to the device, or a failure in the system. If the PCB layout includes a pad for this pin, it should remain unconnected.

SNS.description: Output corresponding sense value based on sense ratio

connected_components.description: A sense resistor connected between the SNS pin and ground. Its value is chosen to optimize the current sense accuracy and the voltage range for the MCU's ADC, considering the desired current range and fault voltage levels. A typical value is 1 kΩ.
The analog output of the SNS pin is fed into the Analog-to-Digital Converter (ADC) of a microcontroller for current monitoring and fault detection.
The state of the DIAG_EN pin controls whether the SNS pin provides analog current sense information or is in a high-impedance state.

implementation.connectivity: For analog current sensing and fault reporting, the SNS pin should be connected to the ground through an external sense resistor (RSNS). For diagnostics, this pin is typically connected to an MCU's analog-to-digital converter (ADC) input. If the analog sense is not needed, the SNS pin can be connected to ground through a 1-kΩ resistor.
implementation.detailed_description: The SNS pin provides an output that corresponds to the sensed load current. This output is proportional to the load current, with a specific sense ratio (KSNS). This allows for accurate current monitoring and diagnostics. In fault conditions, the SNS pin can also indicate a fault by forcing a specific voltage level (VSNSFH) that scales with the DIAG_EN pin voltage, providing a way to report faults without needing external protection components for the MCU's ADC.
implementation.functionality: The SNS pin's functionality depends on the DIAG_EN pin state. When DIAG_EN is HIGH, the SNS pin provides an analog output proportional to the load current. In fault conditions (e.g., overcurrent, thermal shutdown), the SNS pin output is clamped to a high voltage level (VSNSFH). When DIAG_EN is LOW, the SNS pin output is in a high-impedance state, effectively disabling the current sensing and diagnostic reporting through this pin.
precautions: The value of the sense resistor (RSNS) should be carefully chosen to ensure that the voltage on the SNS pin (VSNS) remains within the acceptable input range of the MCU's ADC, both during normal operation and during fault conditions.
The formula (V SNSFH – V HR ) × K SNS / I LOAD,max ≤ R SNS ≤ V ADC,min × K SNS / I LOAD,min should be used to select RSNS for optimal performance.
If the SNS pin is not used for current sensing, it should be connected to ground through a 1-kΩ resistor to prevent floating and potential issues.

SNS.name: SNS

Thermal Pad.description: Thermal Pad, internally shorted to ground

implementation.connected_components: No external components are typically connected directly to the Thermal Pad itself. Its connection is to the PCB's ground plane. The PCB layout should incorporate a sufficient copper area connected to this pad to act as a heatsink.
implementation.connectivity: The Thermal Pad should be connected to the ground plane of the PCB. In a schematic, it should be connected to the device's ground (GND).
implementation.detailed_description: The Thermal Pad is internally connected to the ground of the device. It is designed to help dissipate heat generated by the device during operation.
implementation.functionality: The primary function of the Thermal Pad is for thermal management. It provides a low thermal resistance path for heat to dissipate from the IC to the PCB, thereby helping to keep the junction temperature within its operating limits. Electrically, it is connected to ground.
implementation.precautions: Ensure adequate copper area on the PCB is connected to the Thermal Pad to facilitate efficient heat dissipation. Failure to do so can lead to the device overheating and potentially triggering thermal shutdown or causing permanent damage. When soldering, ensure a good thermal connection is made to the PCB ground plane. If using thermal vias, ensure they are properly plated and not plugged to maintain good thermal conductivity.

Thermal Pad.name: Thermal Pad

VOUT.description: Output of high side switch, connected to load

connected_components.description: The VOUT pin is connected to the intended load of the high-side switch (e.g., resistive, inductive, or capacitive loads).
A small capacitor (e.g., 22 nF) is recommended between VOUT and GND for EMI performance and transient filtering.

implementation.connectivity: The VOUT pin should be connected directly to the load. For improved EMI performance and transient filtering, a small capacitor (e.g., 22 nF) can be connected between VOUT and GND. In some diagnostic scenarios, the output voltage on VOUT is monitored.
implementation.detailed_description: VOUT is the output pin of the high-side switch. It is connected to the load.
implementation.functionality: The VOUT pin serves as the primary output of the TPS1HTC30-Q1. It delivers the switched power to the connected load. The pin also plays a role in diagnostics, such as open-load detection when the device is off.
precautions: Ensure that the voltage and current ratings of the load are within the device's capabilities.
Proper layout is crucial to manage thermal dissipation, especially at higher output currents. Maximize copper coverage and use thermal vias to connect the thermal pad to ground.
When enabling diagnostics, the voltage on the VOUT pin is monitored. Ensure that the measurement circuitry connected to VOUT can handle the expected voltage levels.

connected_components.connection_details: Connect directly to the main power supply (e.g., automotive battery). Multiple VS pins are available (12, 13, 14) and should all be connected.
An optional TVS diode (e.g., SMBJ60CA) can be connected across the VS pin and GND to protect against voltage transients (ISO7637-2 pulses).
An optional bulk capacitor (e.g., 10 uF) can be connected between VS and GND to help filter voltage transients and stabilize the supply rail, especially if the LDO needs to hold its rail.
A 100 nF capacitor is recommended on the input for EMI mitigation, typically placed close to the VS pin.

implementation.connectivity: The VS pin should be connected directly to the vehicle's main power supply (e.g., the battery or a regulated power rail). It is recommended to connect all VS pins (pins 12, 13, and 14) to the power supply for optimal performance and thermal management.
implementation.detailed_description: VS is the power supply pin for the high-side switch. It receives the main input voltage from the automotive battery.
implementation.functionality: The VS pin is the primary power input to the device. It operates across a wide voltage range (6 V to 60 V) and includes overvoltage protection up to 66 V. It powers the internal circuitry, including the NMOS power FET and charge pump.
precautions: Ensure the VS voltage stays within the recommended operating conditions (6 V to 60 V).
The device has overvoltage protection up to 66 V, but sustained operation above the recommended range can impact reliability.
In automotive applications, consider adding transient voltage suppression (TVS) and filtering capacitors to protect against voltage spikes and noise on the power supply line.
Proper PCB layout with adequate copper coverage and thermal vias is crucial for heat dissipation, especially at higher load currents, to prevent thermal shutdown.
When connecting to the power supply, ensure that the reverse battery protection circuit (if used with an external component network) is correctly implemented to prevent damage to the device.
